response: I’m sorry to hear about your struggles with getting restful sleep, especially during such a challenging period of change and grief. While I'm here for supportive listening and guidance within my capabilities as an AI assistant, speaking directly with a professional therapist can provide personalized care that is essential when dealing with complex issues related to mental health. They are equipped to help identify the underlying causes of your sleep disruptions in addition to offering strategies tailored specifically for you. Incorporating mindfulness and relaxation techniques, maintaining a regular sleep schedule, creating an inviting bedroom environment, as well as being attentive to dietary habits could also be beneficial steps towards improving your sleep quality. Please consider seeking out professional help where they can offer more comprehensive assistance based on the depth of what you're experiencing. Sleep is vital for our mental and physical health; taking care of it should be a priority in these trying times, so reaching out to someone who specializes in this area might give your body—and mind—the support needed right now.

Question: It takes me a long time to fall asleep; I’d estimate about two hours. I often have nightmares, starting with being eaten by a monster, and I often wake up frightened and unable to breathe. I believe I started losing sleep after breaking up with a girlfriend of 8 years. Also, my father’s business went bankrupt and my mother has a chronic condition. I was under a lot of stress, and life lost meaning. After improving my life and developing a habit of running and exercise to release stress, my symptoms improved. However in the past couple months, I started losing sleep again and having nightmares without warning. How can I solve this issue?

Answer: First of all, exercise is always beneficial for your physical and emotional health. That's great that you have added this in your routine. Have you also considered altering your diet? Certain foods are linked with poor sleep. For example, alcohol, caffeine, nicotine and high fat content foods do not bode well with quality sleep, especially right before bed time.

Question: I'm not the same anymore, I don't know how to get back to who I am. I'm sad and confused and angry and tired. I don't sleep well.

Answer: Being tired can really affect almost everyone's ability to work through things that make them sad, confused, or angry, among other emotions. If you're having difficulty sleeping, try to get into a habit of going to bed and waking up close to the same time every day. Also consider only using the bed for sleeping so your brain knows that it's time to sleep when you are in bed.
